awd_titl_txt: Imaging and controlling moire interactions in two-dimensional semiconductor heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-dimensional (2D) materials are a single or few atoms thick. These ultra-thin materials exhibit a host of new electronic and other effects that have applications to new technologies, such as high speed computing, solar energy harvesting, and quantum-based technologies. Over the past decade, many 2D materials have been discovered, including 2D metals, semiconductors, and magnets. Furthermore, these 2D materials can be stacked together to realize properties  that are enabled by the interactions between layers.  These new properties enable electronic and optical devices, like transistors, solar cells and lasers. This research is focused on investigating multi-layer 2D material samples that use these interlayer interactions to realize new electronic and optical properties. In particular, by combining two different 2D semiconductors, the research team will explore states with trapped electrons. These trapped electrons can act as quantum light sources, which would help enable quantum communication devices that are secure against cyber-attacks. This research aligns with the NSF Big Idea of the Quantum Leap: Leading the Next Quantum Revolution by developing material systems that have the potential to enable these new quantum information technologies. Furthermore, the project strengthens the STEM workforce both directly and indirectly by training and mentoring graduate, undergraduate, and high school students through the proposed research, and by encouraging interest in STEM at the high school level in southern Arizona.

The stacking of 2D materials in a vertical heterostructure leads to the formation of a long wavelength moiré pattern due to the lattice mismatch and relative orientation between the layers.  This moiré pattern modulates the electronic and optical properties of the heterostructure leading to the confinement of electrons in one layer and holes in the other layer.  These confined indirect excitons are known to serve as resources for quantum information science, and the PI will investigate how the novel physics of moiré confined excitons in 2D semiconductor heterostructures can be exploited to realize quantum devices with new functionalities.  This project is focused on 2D semiconducting transition metal dichalcogenide heterostructures consisting of MoSe2 and WSe2 which form a type-II heterojunction.  The research in this project advances knowledge of quantum materials physics by developing a comprehensive understanding of the role of twist angle and interlayer interactions in transition metal dichalcogenide heterostructures.  In particular, the research has three aims: (1) Image the moiré potential in MoSe2/WSe2 heterostructures using scanning tunneling microscopy, (2) Directly measure spatially modulated moiré exciton emission using low-temperature scanning near field optical microscopy and (3) Control moiré interlayer excitons in 2D heterostructures.  Lastly, modifying the interaction between layers and the potential landscape, allows for the tuning of the interlayer bandgap, the charging of trapped moiré excitons and the condensation of interlayer excitons in the moiré potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit
The overarching goal of this project was to image and control the electronic states in ultra-thin semiconductor devices. Specifically, atomically-thin two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors were studied. The 2D semiconductors were stacked on top of each other to realize electronic states that arise due to the interactions between layers. Each of the 2D semiconductor layers is composed of a repeating crystal of atoms. Stacking two slightly different crystals on top of each other gives rise to a new moire crystal that modifies the materiel's electronic states. In this project, 2D moire samples were fabricated using state-of-the-art nanofabrication techniques, by first isolating and characterizing individual 2D materials, and then stacking them together to make structures that host novel electronic states.
One of the major achievements of this project was the successful imaging of the moire crystal that arises when two different 2D semiconductors are stacked together. This was accomplished using a technique called scanning tunneling microscopy, which allows for the imaging of individual atoms and the ability to measure the local electronic states.  
When two different 2D semiconductor layers are stacked together, they can host an excited electronic state called an interlayer exciton (IX). These IXs are composed of an electron in one layer that is bound to a missing electron (a hole) in the other layer. IXs behave like atoms in that they carry energy (as excited states), and can absorb and emit light allowing for them to be studied using optical techniques. IXs that occur in moire stacked samples are affected by the moire interactions, and one of the major achievements of this project was determining how the alignment of the 2D layers affects IXs. Furthermore, it was determined that the moire interactions between the two 2D semiconductor layers could be suppressed by adding a two-atom-thick 2D insulating layer between the layers. These moire suppressed samples allowed for the IXs to move freely in the structure, and at low temperatures, the IXs were shown to transition to a quantum superfluid phase of matter where IXs can potentially propagate without dissipation.


Broader Impacts
Computers and internet-connected devices have become essential parts of society, which has led to the need to miniaturize the electronic components that are inside of these devices, while also making them more energy efficient to reduce their environmental impact. At the most basic level, electronic and optical components are built of metals, insulators and semiconductors, and modern technologies are nearing the practical limit of the established semiconductors (such as silicon) which are all three-dimensional crystals. The materials and structures studied in this project were all based on atomically-thin 2D crystals which offer new possibilities to realize smaller, lighter and more energy efficient electronic and optical components. By probing the fundamental properties of these 2D crystals, new states of electrons have been discovered that offer potential energy efficiency advantages over traditional semiconductors while operating at the fundamental small-size (atomically-thin) limit. In addition, this project provided research training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students who have learned semiconductor/quantum science, optical/laser measurements, microscopies, and nanofabrication which are highly demanded skills in the high technology workforce.
